LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Tajikistan 
 
The Proposal  The  proposed  Microfinance  Systems  Development  Program 
(MSDP) comprises two loans from the Asian Development Fund's 
resources: (i) a policy loan of $4 million equivalent to support 
policy, legal, and regulatory reforms for microfinance; and (ii) an 
investment  loan  of  $4  million  equivalent  to  help  transform 
nongovernmental organization (NGO) microcredit programs into 
licensed and regulated microfinance institutions (MFIs). 
 
Classification  Poverty Intervention. Thematic: Gender 
 
Environment  Classified as category C 
Assessment   
   
Rationale  Tajikistan has recently made great progress in moving toward a 
market-based  economy.  In  the  past  3  years,  economic 
development  and  transition  have  accelerated,  yet  the  poverty 
incidence remains high. Recent surveys estimated that in 2002 as 
much as 80% of the population is poor.  
 
  The commercial banking sector, in an early stage of development, 
cannot meet the needs of micro- and small enterprises (MSEs) 
and poor households. Rural areas remain largely unserved by 
banks. In contrast, Tajikistan has seen the emergence of a highly 
active and potentially effective microfinance sector. By the end of 
2002, around 17 NGOs were carrying out lending activities, which 
are generally funded through international grant assistance. The 
loans target rural microenterprises and women, and the poor. 
 
  The  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  framework  needs  to  be 
developed so that NGO programs and new MFIs can operate 
legally and under an effective regime of supervision that supports 
prudent  financial  intermediation,  including  deposit  mobilization. 
NGO microcredit programs do not have the capacity to serve the 
microfinance market. However, they have developed a substantial 
level of trust with their clients, registered a high percentage of loan 
repayment, and are developing approaches to sustainability, but 
require  support  in  the  transformation  to  fully  licensed  and 
regulated MFIs. 
 
  The  goal  of  MSDP  is  to  create  a  strong,  commercially  viable 
microfinance  sector.  The  purpose  is  to  establish  a  regulated 
microfinance market in which MSEs and poor households have 
access  to  financial  products  provided  through  sustainable 
microfinance institutions.

iv   
The Sector Development  MSDP  components  include  (i)  development  of  policy,  legal, 
Program  regulatory, and institutional measures to develop a microfinance 
industry; (ii) capacity building for the National Bank of Tajikistan 
(NBT) in regulating and supervising MFIs; (iii) capacity building for 
NGOs  being  transformed  into  formally  licensed  and  regulated 
MFIs;  and  (iv)  an  investment  component  piloting  the 
transformation of selected NGO microcredit programs. 
 
The Policy Loan      The  purpose  is  to  create  a  legal,  regulatory,  and  supervisory 
Objectives And Scope  environment  that  supports  the  development  of  a  strong, 
commercially viable microfinance sector. The components include 
(i) adopting a strategy and policy to develop the microfinance 
sector;  (ii)  developing  an  effective  legal  and  regulatory 
environment for microfinance; and (iii) establishing institutions to 
oversee the development of microfinance. 
 
Policy Framework and  The key reform measures include (i) introduction of a government 
Actions  policy  statement  for  microfinance;  (ii)  establishment  of  a 
microfinance  policy  steering  committee  (MPSC); 
(iii) establishment  of  a  technical  working  group  (TWG); 
(iv) introduction  of  a  law  on  microfinance  organizations; 
(v) harmonizing of laws and regulations on MFIs, with Parliament 
approving amendments; (vi) NBT approval of regulations for MFIs; 
and  (vii)  issuance  of  operating  licenses  to  two  deposit-taking 
MFIs. 
 
 Loan Amount and Terms   A loan of SDR2.934 million ($4 million equivalent) is proposed 
  from Asian Development Fund (ADF) resources. The loan will 
  have an amortization period of 24 years, including a grace period 
  of 8 years, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% during the 
  grace period and 1.5% thereafter.

Tranching  equivalent,  will  be  released  on  loan  effectiveness,  and  the 
second, $2.5 million equivalent, within two years of the date of 
loan  effectiveness,  subject  to  compliance  with  the  agreed-on 
conditions. An incentive tranche of $1 million equivalent will be 
considered for release before the second tranche if the law on 
microfinance  organizations  is  ratified  by  Parliament,  and 
regulations for MFIs are approved by NBT. 
 
Executing Agency  NBT  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  will  cooperate  on  the 
reform measures with the ministries of finance, justice, and state 
revenues and duties. A project management unit (PMU) will be 
established in NBT. 
 
 Procurement  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the foreign exchange 
costs  of  items  produced  and  procured  in  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB) member countries, excluding negative listed items.

v

(i) legal and regulatory framework, (ii) establishment of MFIs, (iii)

Benefits And Impact  MSDP  will  provide  an  improved  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory 
environment  that  will  allow  the  formalization  of  unregulated 
financial  activity.  An  enabling  environment  combined  with 
substantial capacity building will result in the transformation of 
existing NGO microcredit programs into licensed and regulated 
MFIs. New ones may also be established to increase diversity 
within the financial sector. Through the licensing of at least two 
deposit-taking MFIs, the number of borrowers will increase from 
15,000 to 38,000 in five years, and increase MFIs’ loan portfolio to 
$4 million. Formalized microcredit provided through viable MFIs 
will benefit thousands of MSEs, which rely mainly on their own 
savings to fund their activities. With improved, constant access to 
loans, MSEs can expand, benefiting the owners and their families 
directly, and the broader economy indirectly. MSEs, the poor, and 
rural  dwellers  will  benefit  directly  from  accessible  facilities  to 
safeguard savings. 
 
Risks and Safeguards  The  main  risks  facing  the  project  are  (i)  an  unstable 
macroeconomic  environment  that  impacts  negatively  on 
subsectors where MSEs operate, (ii) ineffective implementation of 
the law on microfinance organizations and regulations, (iii) delays 
or difficulties in harmonizing related laws and the tax code as they 
relate to MFIs, (iv) delays or problems in the transformation and/or 
establishment  of  MFIs,  (v)  operational  and  financial  risks  of 
participating commercial banks (PCBs), and (vi) operational and 
financial risks of MFIs. 
 
All  these  will  be  addressed  by  mitigating  measures.  The 
Government's  continued  commitment  to  reform  has  been 
demonstrated in the Poverty Reduction Growth Facility recently 
signed  with  the  International  Monetary  Fund.  Continued 
engagement  with  IMF  and  World  Bank,  and  an  improving 
government  record  in  economic  management  are  the  key 
mitigants to risk (i). Consulting services under the investment loan 
will  provide  expertise  and  resources  to  NBT  to  prudently 
implement the law on microfinance organizations, and create an 
effective regulatory and supervisory regime, which will mitigate 
risk (ii).  
 
  The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) 
and International Finance Corporation (IFC) have signaled their 
support  for  Parliament’s  passing  the  law  on  microfinance 
organizations, and for harmonizing it with existing laws and the tax 
code.

vii
  The  combined  funding  resources  and  commitment  represent 
mitigating factors for risk (iii). The creation of the MPSC and TWG 
will  provide  for  continuous  consultation  and  identification  of 
contentious  issues,  thereby  serving  as  a  mitigant  to  risk  (iv), 
further mitigated by substantial ADB TA resources to transform 
MFIs.  The  commitment  of  USAID  and  IFC  to  individual  NGO 
programs and their transformation further reduces the risk of (iv). 
PCBs’  operational  and  financial  risk  will  be  mitigated  by  strict 
criteria and performance monitoring developed under the project, 
supported by consulting services, thus mitigating risk (v). MFIs’ 
operational  and  financial  risks  referred  to  in  item  (vi)  will  be 
mitigated through training and institutional capacity building to be 
provided to MFIs through the attached TA. Operational risk can be 
further mitigated by MFI borrowing on the credit line to finance the 
purchase  of  appropriate  Information  technology  systems  to 
improve accounting and financial reporting.  
   
Technical Assistance  The objective of the TA is to develop viable MFIs capable of 
serving the poor. The purpose is to strengthen the supervisory 
capacity of NBT and the capacity of MFIs to provide microfinance 
services efficiently and cost-effectively. The total cost of the TA is 
estimated at $776,200 equivalent, comprising local currency and 
foreign currency costs. ADB will finance $640,000 equivalent, and 
the Government and NGOs the balance of $136,200 equivalent in 
kind. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the ADB-
funded TA Special Fund. ADB will recruit individual consultants in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by ADB 
and its Borrowers.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on two proposed 
loans to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Microfinance Systems Development Program (MSDP). 
The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Institutional Strengthening of 
Microfinance Systems, and if the Board approves the proposed loans, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES1 
A.  Macroeconomic Context 
2.  Since independence in 1991, Tajikistan has been in transition to a market-oriented 
economy. The macroeconomic situation has steadily improved, with significant growth and 
stabilization supported by structural reforms.2 Economic growth gained momentum after 1997, 
although the Russian crisis caused a downturn in gross domestic product (GDP) growth from 
5.3% in 1998 to 3.7% in 1999. Following increased cotton and aluminum production, which 
together account for about two thirds of export earnings, GDP growth rebounded 8.3% in 2000, 
10.0% in 2001, and 8.0% in 2002. Inflation stabilized at 27.5% in 1999, but slid to 38.6% in 2001 
due to external factors and problematic implementation of monetary policy. The International 
Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates inflation to decline to 13% in 2002, and further to 5% by 2004.  
 
3.  Tajikistan is highly dependent on foreign trade, with exports constituting 70% of GDP. 
The external current account deficit increased from 6.6% of GDP in 2000 to 7.0% in 2001. 
Gross foreign exchange reserves stood at 2.1 months of imports at the end of 2001. 
 
4.  During the May 2001 Consultative Group Meeting a financing gap of $26 million was 
estimated in the budget for 2002. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) agreed to provide 
assistance for the ongoing transition reform agenda, particularly in rural finance and agriculture. 
Tajikistan has a high publicly guaranteed external debt burden equivalent to 87% of GDP, due 
to large nonconcessional bilateral borrowings. IMF imposed a debt ceiling of 3% of GDP on the 
externally  financed  Public  Investment  Program  beginning  in  2002.  Under  the  $128-million 
Poverty Reduction Growth Facility (PRGF) (1999–2001), the Government failed to meet all its 
structural adjustment targets and misreported external debt levels. IMF introduced a staff-
monitored program from October 2001. An $87-million 3-year PRGF was signed in December 
2002.  
 
5.  Tajikistan, one of the poorest republics of the former Soviet Union (FSU), stands out as 
one of the poorest countries in Asia. Despite progress made since independence, overall living 
standards have deteriorated drastically, particularly in rural areas, due to the civil war, general 
economic contraction, and loss of social services. Tajikistan ranks 110th among 174 states 
based on the human development index, with an estimated per capita gross national product

6.  Poverty in rural areas, where 75% of the people live, is more acute than in urban areas. 
The proportion of people living in extreme poverty is 23.4% in rural areas, and 18.6% in urban 
areas. Only 56% of able-bodied citizens are formally employed, leaving nearly half the working 
population to look for income-generating opportunities on their own. Poor people engage in a 
number of such activities to make ends meet. In the poorest households, the single largest 
source of income accounts for only a third of total household income.  
 
7.  The  most  vulnerable  groups  include  pensioners,  the  disabled,  single-headed  family 
households, families with five or more children, teachers, doctors, and the unemployed. An 
important finding of the Tajik Living Standards Survey was that financial hardship is not limited 
to the poorest. Over 25% of all households have sold assets and about 33% have borrowed 
money to buy food. 
 
8.  Poverty has a gender dimension. While poverty incidence does not vary between men 
and women, the transition has affected women disproportionately due to (i) the collapse of the 
social allowance and services; (ii) women’s income being four times lower than men’s; (iii) 
female-headed households having less access to land, irrigation, and agriculture; (iv) women’s 
unemployment being marginally higher than men’s;4 and (v) women being employed mainly in 
the  low-paid  sectors  such  as  agriculture,  education,  and  health.  The  Government  has  set 
poverty reduction as its primary objective, requiring a comprehensive and long-term strategy. 
The National Poverty Reduction Strategy, endorsed by Parliament on 24 June 2002, focuses on 
(i) accelerated, socially fair, labor-intensive, and export-oriented economic growth; (ii) efficient 
and fair provision of basic social services; (iii) targeted support to the poorest groups of the 
population; and (iv) efficient governance and improvement in security. 
 
9.  Microfinance  reduces  poverty.  The  small  number  of  micro-  and  small  enterprises 
(MSEs), poor households, and rural dwellers who have access to microcredit have benefited 
from increased and stable incomes. Microfinance is limited to microcredit. Access to small loans 
provides working capital to simple businesses that need cash. In a very poor country such as 
Tajikistan, where people have little savings, credit is one of the few sources of investment 
capital.  Microcredit  is  fueling  thousands  of  rural  MSEs,  and  its  provision  must  be 
institutionalized. New financial services, especially deposit taking, are also important. As MSEs 
grow, they generate small surpluses that can be reinvested or used to meet household needs. 
Case studies from nongovernment organization (NGO) microcredit programs in Supplementary 
Appendix 1 document the positive impact of microfinance on poverty reduction.

11.  NBT has been strengthened but the financial position and operational efficiency of banks

12.  In 2002 banking sector assets accounted for about 14% of GDP. The amount of lending 
to the cotton sector is estimated to be 12% of GDP (7% in 1999). Credit to the non-cotton 
private sector represents barely 2% of GDP. The extreme and growing concentration of lending 
to the cotton sector, given its vulnerability to external price shocks, has a predictably deleterious 
effect on system-wide loan recovery. Interest rates on commercial bank loans of 3–6-month 
tenor average 25-30% per annum, while the rates on 3–6-month term deposits are close to 
22%. The high deposit rates reflect the lack of public confidence in banks, which must offer high 
rates to the public and are, in turn, rewarded with little deposit activity. Rates on treasury bills 
average about 15%. NBT's discount rate for loans to commercial banks was 20% in February 
2003. Loans are mainly short term.  
 
13.  Tajikistan suffers from the lowest degree of monetization among members of FSU. The 
deposit base of banks was close to $28 million at the end of 2001, equivalent to only 20% of 
private sector credits, compared to an international norm of around 120% or more. Banks 
appear to be increasing their deposit taking, reflecting increased confidence in the currency, as 
well as positive real interest rates. The volume of Tajik workers' remittances flowing in from 
abroad  is  increasing.  Still,  the  overall  level  of  deposits  remains  low,  with  total  deposits 
equivalent to 4% of GDP.6 The banking sector has yet to prove itself capable of mobilizing 
savings from the public and channeling loans to creditworthy borrowers.

2.  Nongovernment Organizations and Microfinance 
15.  NGO microcredit activities commenced in 1993 with the Aga Khan Foundation (AKF) 
through  its  Aga  Khan  Development  Network  (AKDN).  These  programs  have  focused  on 
humanitarian relief and poverty reduction with microcredit as a component of more diversified 
programs.  These  NGOs  have  been  financed  by  multilateral  and  bilateral  agencies,  and 
international NGOs, mostly on a grant basis. 
 
16.  The country’s 17 microcredit programs mostly target the rural poor, mainly women and 
vulnerable groups. In most NGO microcredit programs, over 50% of clients, sometimes nearly 
100%, are women. Twelve programs include cash disbursements, and the rest provide credit in 
kind. By the end of 2001, NGO microcredit programs had disbursed cash loans of more than 
$6.6 million to 44,000 borrowers7 and had an aggregate loan portfolio of $3.0 million, with an 
average borrower balance of $94. Around 20,000 more families receive credit in kind. The 
seven largest NGOs, each with a cash loan portfolio exceeding $100,000, account for 94% of all 
borrowers and 97% of total loans outstanding as of the end of 2001. The microfinance market is 
dominated  by  three  NGOs:  AKDN,  National  Association  of  Business  Women  in  Tajikistan 
(NABWT), and Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development (ACTED), accounting for 
nearly 80% of clients. Four NGOs (AKDN, NABWT, ACTED, and the Development Fund) 
account for 85% of loans outstanding. Six of the larger NGOs had an aggregate 37% growth in 
clients and 79% growth in loan portfolio in 2001. While the aggregate NGO loan portfolio was 
equal to 6% of banking sector assets in 2001, it involved three times the number of households 
served by the banking sector.  
 
17.  NGO credit programs serve far more customers than banks by offering microloans to the 
poor. Most microlending is to groups: 95% by number of loans and 75% by loan amount. 
Lending is commonly for 1–3 months for group-based borrowers and 12 months for individual 
borrowers. Most groups have 7–12 members. Individual-member loan size within groups is 
usually $20–100, and for individuals, usually $300–$3,000, up to $5,000. Interest rates on group 
lending are 2–4% per month and around 2% per month for individual lending. Most lending is 
denominated in dollars but disbursed in somoni. Most lending is in the rural areas. Only three 
NGOs lend in urban areas, and mainly to groups. Three NGOs have achieved loan recovery 
rates higher than 98% of total lending. Loan loss rates in individual lending have been less than 
for group lending. Unlike banks, NGO credit programs have developed a culture of repayment 
among clients. The high rates of repayment in microfinance also demonstrate that the credit 
products and underwriting standards and methodology used are appropriate. 
 
18.  The collection of savings is common to many group lending programs, with saved funds 
accumulated within the groups and re-lent to members. Poor rural households, in groups, save 
TJS0.5–2.0 ($0.08–2.0) each per month. For wealthier households, savings of TJS20 ($8.00) 
per month per person are common. One program has more than $53,000 in voluntary savings, 
and another, more than $15,000 in compulsory savings.

C.  Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Viable and Sustainable Institutions 
20.  Tajikistan  has  a  relatively  young,  underdeveloped,  and  inefficient  financial  sector 
dominated by a few banks. The banking subsector and the smaller set of unlicensed and 
unregulated  NGOs  together  are  unable  to  meet  the  demand  for  basic  financial  services. 
Demand for financial services of all kinds is vast and unmet. Rural enterprises and farming 
households, which often engage in a variety of income-generating on- and off-farm activities, 
have little access to credit due to limited funds, perceived high risk of agriculture activity, and 
high administration costs in making small loans. Savings mobilization, particularly in rural areas, 
is almost nonexistent.  
 
21.  Assuming that 20% of rural and 10% of urban households make up the market for 
microfinance, at least 150,000 households, or nearly five times the present combined outreach 
of all NGO microcredit programs, could benefit from microfinance. Most rural households are 
without access to deposit services. Based on trends registered in the past two years by NGOs, 
an annual growth rate of 17.5% in numbers of households would yield an outreach of 150,000 
households in 10 years. Satisfying projected loan demand, assuming small individual loans of 
$50–300, would require $25 million in new lending. Aggregate NGO microlending for 2001 was 
$3 million. Achieving an average household savings balance of $30 per year for 300,000 rural 
households would provide a rural savings balance of $9 million, an amount equal to total 
domestic currency deposits held by banks in 2000. Financial service providers need to be 
encouraged to intensify efforts to provide services to this large potential market. 
 
22.  Viable and sustainable financial institutions capable of providing basic financial services 
to  the  public  are  almost  completely  lacking.  None  of  the  NGOs  have  achieved  financial 
sustainability. Inadequate accounting, portfolio, and management information systems reflect 
weak  governance  and  internal  control.  Financial  intermediation  activities  are  inadequately 
separated from social ones with regard to financial reporting and staffing. The range of financial 
products is limited. The present volume of business is insufficient to allow for full cost recovery 
on operations and the creation of an equity base out of profits. Focus on organizational and 
financial planning is lacking. Recently, however, three NGOs have begun to become more 
commercialized and specialized microfinance institution (MFIs) through (i) separation of head 
office from branch operations, (ii) adoption of new charts of accounts to produce financial 
statements that relate only to microfinance activities, (iii) a search for appropriate accounting 
and management software, (iv) reorganization of departments and reallocation of staff, (v) 
improvements in internal controls (particularly internal audit), (vi) separation of oversight from 
operational functions, and (vii) a search for appropriate forms of legal entity and ownership. 
 
23.  For  all  their  limitations,  NGOs  are  providing  the  bulk  of  rural  financial  services. 
Substantial trust already exists between NGOs and their customers, which is a sound basis for 
operation  expansion.  While  NGO  programs  have  institutional  weaknesses,  many  are  now 
examining ways to become commercially viable. Funds to expand lending, however, will need to

come from a balanced mix of deposit mobilization, borrowings, and equity capital, which will 
only be attracted by an appropriate institutional form, maintenance of a well-performing loan 
portfolio, and close and responsive ties with communities. Market demand assumes financial 
growth and customer outreach far in excess of the grant resources and/or loan financing likely 
to  be  made  available  to  NGOs  from  international  or  other  external  sources.  Therefore, 
intervention is warranted to develop a sustainable microfinance sector to expand access by the 
poor and rural dwellers to financial services.  
 
2.  Policy on Microfinance 
24.  The enabling environment for microfinance suffers from the absence of defined policies 
and mechanisms, hindering NGO microcredit programs from becoming commercially viable 
providers of diversified financial services. The Government aims to create a formal microfinance 
sector,  in  which  some  NGO  microcredit  programs  will  be  transformed  into  licensed  and 
regulated MFIs. The development policy letter (Appendix 3) indicates the Government's strong 
support for the creation of a new, fully regulated financial subsector free of the enormous 
problems of the banks, and targeting most of the population with basic financial services. The 
policy  letter  recognizes  the  Government's  responsibility  to  establish  an  enabling  legal  and 
regulatory environment for microfinance and encourages NGOs to become regulated MFIs.  
 
3.  Existing Legislation 
25.  NGOs are registered under the Law on Public Organizations, which applies only to 
NGOs supported by external funding. The Law on State Registration of Juridical Persons and 
Law on Joint Stock Companies cover the registration of various commercial and noncommercial 
entities, which depends on the form of organization and ownership. Individuals and enterprises, 
however, are required to register as a juridical person, and both are assumed to make a profit 
and so are subject to a variety of taxes. Registration as a noncommercial entity, which would 
logically mean being exempt from profit or income tax (but not necessarily from other taxes), is 
generally  not  allowed.  Given  the  changing  status  of  legislation  for  registration,  and  the 
implications of registering as a commercial or noncommercial entity, it is not clear under which 
laws NGO credit programs should operate.  
 
26.  Licensing of financial institutions is the responsibility of NBT. Whether NGOs operating 
microcredit programs should also be registered and licensed with NBT is unclear. As NGOs and 
MFIs will operate varying microfinance programs involving different levels of deposit, credit, and 
transfer services, a classification system of various microfinance organizations with relevant 
registration and licensing requirements and procedures is required. 
 
27.  NGOs  operating  microcredit  programs  now  do  so  largely  under  international 
agreements, thereby removing them from most legislation, including the Tax Code. But the legal 
and regulatory environment focuses on banks and does not provide for the legal establishment 
and  operation  of  NGO  microcredit  programs  and  potential  MFIs.  Laws  do  not  specifically 
recognize MFIs. They operate differently from other financial institutions, particularly commercial 
banks, and the legislation needs to reflect these differences.8  
 
28.  The  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)  and  International 
Finance Corporation (IFC), in close consultation with ADB, support the drafting of the law on

4.  Regulation and Supervision 
30.  While  the  reform  measures  have  reduced  the  number  of  banks,  ongoing  bank 
restructurings still burden the 32 NBT Supervision Department staff members, who must resolve 
issues of bank liquidations, bank mergers, and recapitalization; oversee installation and use of 
international  accounting  standards  (IAS)  in  all  banks;  improve  off-  and  on-site  monitoring 
systems and procedures; and deal with continuing financial and management weaknesses of 
remaining banks. Supervision is made more difficult by the large number of bank branches 
(130) and representative offices (over 130). To supervise MFIs, NBT will need more resources 
and staff, who will require intensive training. Staff will need to develop regulations for MFIs, 
license them, review and analyze regular reports received from them, and inspect them on site 
to enforce compliance with regulations.  
 
D.  Lessons Learned 
31.  ADB has considerable experience with microfinance operations in several countries but 
limited experience in the FSU transition economies, particularly in transforming NGO microcredit 
programs into licensed and regulated MFIs. MSDP will be ADB’s first experience with a broad 
sector  development  program  in  a  transition  economy.9  Lessons  are  drawn  from  ADB’s 
experience in rural finance from transition economies, and from transformation operations in 
other countries. 
 
32.  The lessons10 highlight the importance of (i) following a financial systems development 
approach to provide an enabling environment for commercial microfinance, (ii) focusing on poor 
clients to reduce poverty, (iii) working within the capacity of participating financial institutions to 
minimize distraction from their main functions and to avoid raising their administrative costs, and 
(iv) maximizing the impact of capacity building by providing TA over a period of time and not as 
an isolated instance. Because rural financial markets consist of different market segments with 
markedly diverse characteristics, a multiagency approach is necessary to meet different sectors’ 
demand for financial services.  
 
33.  ADB has two ongoing projects to establish savings and credit union systems in the 
Kyrgyz Republic and Mongolia.11 Key lessons include the following:

F.  Rationale 
46.  Tajikistan has a young and underdeveloped financial sector that cannot meet demand 
for basic financial services. NGOs provide the bulk of financial services, particularly in rural 
areas. NGOs have already trained a large number of groups of rural people in basic lending 
services, and to a more limited extent, in savings modalities. NGOs and Government, however, 
need to develop the capacity to manage and regulate formal MFIs. The policy, legal, regulatory, 
and institutional environment is not appropriate to MFIs, which will thus be unable to reach 
significant  scale  and  provide  financial  services  reliably  and  in  a  sustainable  manner. 
Government and externally provided funds are insufficient to meet demand for microcredit. 
Institutional capacity to deliver financial services on a sustainable basis, including deposit-taking 
services, is needed. MSDP recognizes that the bulk of MFI resources must come from the 
economy as savings mobilization stimulated through sound, sustainable, and regulated MFIs. 
Therefore, an enabling environment is essential, as is the capacity of NGOs to be transformed 
into viable MFIs. 
 
47.  To foster growth, innovation, and diversity of financial institutions, including MFIs, a 
comprehensive financial systems development approach is required. It is in accordance with 
ADB’s microfinance development strategy.17 The proposed MSDP is in line with the four pillars 
of  this  strategy:  (i)  creating  an  enabling  policy  environment;  (ii)  improving  the  financial 
infrastructure, specifically the legal and regulatory environment; (iii) building the institutional 
strength of MFIs to enhance their sustainability and outreach; and (iv) encouraging innovative 
programs that support the poor.

III.  THE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Program Objectives and Scope 
48.  The goal of MSDP is to create a strong, commercially viable microfinance sector. The 
purpose is to establish a regulated microfinance market in which MSEs and poor households 
have access to financial products provided through sustainable MFIs. The program framework 
is in Appendix 2. 
 
49.  The components include (i) the adoption of policy, regulatory, and institutional actions to 
develop a microfinance industry; (ii) capacity building for NBT to regulate and supervise MFIs, 
and  for  NGOs  to  become  formally  licensed  and  regulated  MFIs;  and  (iii)  an  investment 
component  piloting  the  transformation  of  selected  NGO  microcredit  programs  into  formally 
licensed and regulated MFIs. 
 
B.  Special Features 
50.  MSDP will take steps to develop microfinance in Tajikistan. ADB and the Government 
recognize the important role that existing NGO microcredit programs can play in developing 
financial markets. Specifically, MSDP will help the Government establish a comprehensive 
policy,  legal,  regulatory,  and  institutional  framework  to  develop  a  viable  and  sustainable 
industry. This is of particular importance in a country recently emerging from civil war, while 
adopting a reform agenda to move to a market-oriented system, where an enabling environment 
for microfinance does not yet exist. This is the first time ADB will take such a comprehensive 
approach in a transition economy (footnote 9). 
 
51.  MSDP is also involved with NGOs and their transformation into licensed and regulated 
MFIs.  Several  NGO  credit  programs  have  already  been  transformed  into  formal  financial 
institutions.  While  ADB  has  supported  various  microfinance  programs,  including  the 
establishment of NGO microcredit programs, Grameen replicators, and creation of savings and 
credit unions systems, ADB has not exclusively focused on transforming NGOs into formal 
MFIs. These special features require a consultative and flexible approach, involving all key 
stakeholders.  
 
C.  The Policy Loan 
52.  The policy loan requires the Government to implement a set of agreed-on measures to 
improve the operating environment for existing NGO microcredit programs and their subsequent 
transformation into licensed and regulated MFIs. The Government’s development policy letter 
and a policy matrix are in Appendixes 3 and 4, respectively. 
 
1.  Objectives 
53.  The purpose of the MSDP policy loan is to create a legal, regulatory, and supervisory 
environment  that  supports  the  development  of  a  strong,  commercially  viable  microfinance 
sector. This environment will allow for the establishment, operation, and growth of a diversified 
range of institutions offering microfinance services. These institutions could include those that 
are (i) unregistered and unregulated, (ii) accredited and nonprudentially supervised, and (iii) 
formally licensed and prudentially supervised.

2.  Components and Outputs 
54.  The policy loan has four components, outlined below with their expected outputs and 
summarized in a policy matrix (Appendix 4), which identifies monitoring mechanisms, identifies 
responsible agencies, and lists an implementation time frame. 
 
a.  Policy and Strategy 
55.  A government policy and strategy for microfinance development will provide a framework 
to establish an enabling environment. Policy and strategy should be comprehensive and include 
a sector agenda. The Government has submitted a policy letter to ADB as a condition for first 
tranche release. The Government will keep ADB informed of policy discussions with other 
multilateral and bilateral aid agencies that might have an impact on the program, and will 
provide  ADB  with  an  opportunity  to  comment  on  any  resulting  policy  proposals.  The 
Government will consider ADB’s  views before finalizing and implementing any such proposals. 
 
b.  Legal Environment 
56.  A number of laws will require revision to provide an appropriate framework to support the 
establishment and development of microfinance institutions. Under ADB TA 3555 (footnote 1) a 
legal specialist with a team of NBT staff reviewed the relevant legislation and identified a 
program  for  change.  Further  discussion  with  Government,  NBT,  NGOs,  and  other  funding 
agencies established the following requirements: 
 
57.  Classification  of  Microfinance  Institutions.  A  classification  of  MFIs  should  be 
developed to clarify the status of all NGO microcredit programs and future MFIs, and issues 
related to registration and licensing, plus applicable legal and regulatory requirements. The draft 
microfinance  law  prepared  by  the  USAID/IFC  team  distinguishes  a  range  of  institutions 
providing  MF  services  and  establishes  the  legal  basis  for  (i)  microcredit  foundations,  and 
registered  NGO  microcredit  programs  that  make  microloans  with  funding  agencies  funds; 
(ii) microlending  companies,  which  are  licensed  and  registered,  have  commercial  funding 
sources but do not take deposits, and make microloans; and (iii) microcredit deposit companies, 
which take deposits from the public and make microloans.  
 
58.  Adoption of a Microfinance Law. The draft law is being circulated for comment among 
stakeholders, including ADB, and is expected to be submitted to Parliament for approval by 
June 2003. The draft law does not consider cooperatives, so a separate law on cooperatives will 
likely be necessary. 
 
59.  Harmonizing of the Draft Microfinance Law with Relevant Laws. The final enactment 
of a microfinance law will require amendments to laws on the national bank of Tajikistan and on 
banks and banking activities to (i) provide for the taking of savings deposits for MFIs from 
borrowers, members, and the public; (ii) clarify the application of the provision on licensing; and 
(iii) harmonize the microfinance law with other legislation. MSDP consulting services will ensure 
that the draft law is harmonized with relevant laws.  
 
60.  Review of the Tax Code. It will be reviewed and amended to include MFIs and provide 
for a fair tax regime appropriate to their objectives and activities.  
 
61.  New legislation is being developed and existing laws reviewed and revised through a 
consultative process involving all key stakeholders, including relevant government agencies

13 
such  as  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  Ministry  of  Justice  (MOJ),  NBT,  NGOs  engaged  in 
microfinance, and funding agencies. 
 
c.  Regulation and Supervision 
62.  NBT regulations 83 and 84, and draft resolution 19 provide for the registration, licensing, 
and regulation of loan societies and nonbank financial institution generally. These regulations 
will be superseded by those to be drafted pursuant to the draft law. It provides a suitable 
general framework to establish MFIs, lays out operational parameters, and tasks the NBT to 
develop regulations and supervise MFIs. A comprehensive set of prudential and nonprudential 
regulations, readily available to institutions and the public, will be prepared for all institutions 
providing  microfinance  services.  The  regulations  should  include  the  following:  entry 
requirements,  ownership  restrictions,  minimum  capital  and  capital  adequacy  requirements, 
reserves and loan loss provisioning, requirements for loan security, an asset classification 
scheme,  limitations  on  risk  concentration,  liquidity  reserve  requirements,  management 
qualifications and similar requirements, limitations on types of financial services authorized, 
internal supervision requirements, audit requirements, and external supervision.  
 
63.  NBT has limited resources as the sole regulatory agency. It must, however, develop the 
capacity to supervise licensed and regulated MFIs. Such capacity will include effective off-site 
monitoring systems that fit with a set of performance indicators and provide early warning of 
potential  problems,  and  systems  and  procedures,  accompanied  by  manuals,  for  on-site 
supervision. The MSDP investment loan component will help build such capacity. 
 
d.  Institutional Environment 
64.  An  effective  regulatory  and  supervisory  regime  should  be  developed  through  a 
consultative process involving policymakers and practitioners. Institutions should be established 
to oversee the development of the microfinance sector, including a microfinance policy steering

D.  Investment Loan 
1.  Objectives 
73.  The purpose of the MSDP investment loan is to expand the outreach and sustainability 
of MFIs serving MSEs and poor households by transforming unregulated credit programs to 
licensed, regulated financial institutions. By the end of the project it is expected that (i) at least 
two deposit-taking MFIs will be operating in full compliance with all regulatory requirements; (ii) 
MFI outreach will have increased by 100%, with about 75% of clients being initially poor, and 
50% being women; (iii) MFI savings deposits will reach about 10% of loans outstanding; (iv) MFI 
loans outstanding will reach about TJS9 million ($3.5 million); and (v) MFI loan losses will be 
less than 4%. 
 
2.  Components and Outputs 
74.  The project scope has four components: (i) regulatory framework, (ii) establishment of 
MFIs,  (iii)  institutional  strengthening,  and  (iv)  project  management.  The  project  scope  is 
nationwide, with geographical focus on locations where selected NGOs willing to transform to 
MFIs have existing microfinance programs. 
 
a.  Regulatory Framework 
75.  A legal and regulatory environment favorable to MFI operations is a prerequisite to the 
formation of legally registered and licensed MFIs. By agreement, USAID and IFC are providing 
TA to prepare the draft law. Through this component, ADB will focus on developing regulations 
and  increasing  community  awareness  of  all  laws  and  regulations,  and  MFI  activities. 
Regulations will be prepared through a consultative process with key stakeholders, largely 
conducted through the TWG, comprising Government, NBT and NGO representatives (para. 
99).  
b.  Establishment of Microfinance Institution 
76.  In parallel with the development of a favorable legal and regulatory environment, the 
project will focus on the transformation of selected NGO microcredit programs into licensed and 
regulated MFIs. The project will work with existing NGO credit programs that have (i) registered 
as a local NGO, (ii) at least three years experience in Tajikistan providing credit, (iii) at least one 
year’s experience in delivering cash credit to groups and/or individuals, (iv) loan losses of less 
than 4%, and (v) a willingness and capacity to meet the licensing and regulation requirements to 
be defined by NBT regulations. These and other criteria for selecting NGO programs will be 
subject to government and ADB approval. Graduation programs for selected NGO programs will 
be developed. 
 
77.  The project will work with selected NGOs to establish institutional forms. NGOs will 
become either shareholder-owned institutions or member-owned institutions such as savings

16    
and credit unions. With advice and assistance from the project, NGOs will decide on the type of 
institutional form to adopt. The project will help NGOs prepare business plans, strategies, 
systems and procedures, and operating standards to transform and operate an MFI. During 
transformation, NGOs will provide regularly updated reports on their operations, performance, 
and status of transformation. Financial and management reporting and internal controls will be 
consistent with Consultative Group on Assisting the Poorest (CGAP) guidelines. 
 
78.  Once the MFI is licensed it will be eligible for a credit line initially for one year and 
subsequently for up to 10 years, depending on performance, subject to credit-line participation 
criteria specified below. MFIs will also have to develop diversified savings and loan products 
and other services. As the project will focus on savings, it will emphasize development of at 
least two savings products such as passbook accounts and term deposits for all MFIs.  
 
79.  The project will also explore promoting and establishing microfinance services in rural 
areas through commercial banks. The possibility of a partner arrangement between MFIs and a 
commercial bank will be considered. 
 
80.  Established MFIs will be in the early stage of developing credit and savings services. 
MFIs will have little credibility with commercial banks and may have difficulty obtaining financing 
through them. Since deposit mobilization must be backed by adequate liquidity or access to 
liquidity, appropriate liquidity mechanisms are required. To provide sufficient liquidity under 
normal operations, MFIs will be expected to hold a portion of their assets in near-liquid form, 
probably on term deposit with a reputable bank. So that sufficient funds are available for 
unexpected customer withdrawals, a pilot liquidity guarantee fund (LGF) should be established 
to provide short-term funds to MFIs on terms similar to the refinance facility provided through 
NBT for commercial banks. An LGF of $100,000 equivalent will be financed in equal parts by 
the Government/NBT and ADB.  
 
81.  To be eligible to draw down against LGF, MFIs must comply with NBT regulations and 
maintain standard levels of liquidity before the need for funds. Based on the amount of savings 
and paid-up capital, the amount an MFI can draw on will be limited, with a draw-down up to 90 
days. LGF should be able to make funds available within 24 hours. LGF operational procedures 
will  be  prepared  and  agreed  on  by  the  Government/NBT,  ADB,  and  NGOs/MFIs.  Further 
development or dissolution will be agreed on at project completion. 
 
c.  Institutional Strengthening 
82.  While NGOs have been operating credit programs in Tajikistan since 1995, Government 
and NGOs have limited experience in supervising and operating MFIs. Before, during, and after 
NGO programs become MFIs, relevant training must be provided to NBT and NGOs/MFIs.  
83.  While NBT has experience in supervising banks, it does not have the capacity and 
expertise to supervise MFIs. Their supervision will be the responsibility of the Supervision 
Department  for  banks.  To  strengthen  NBT,  the  project  will  support  the  establishment  of 
supervision  capacity  by  hiring  two  more  staff;  providing  training  in  accounting,  legal,  and 
regulatory issues, and on-site supervision of MFIs; and providing a study course abroad in 
microfinance and supervision. Supervision methods will be reviewed and modified for MFIs. 
New procedures will be introduced and operating manuals prepared. NBT will then be expected 
to effectively monitor MFIs off site and supervise them on site.

17 
84.  The transformation of NGO programs into MFIs will require substantial training to ensure 
that staff have the capability to manage and operate a licensed and fully regulated financial 
institution. Head office staff, branch managers, and field supervisors will have to be trained in a 
range of areas. At the field level, training will be on the job and supported by operation manuals. 
NGOs have their own approaches to training but all training must provide staff with the skills 
required. The project will support the preparation of operating procedures and manuals, and 
assess approaches for a system of incentive payments for good staff performance. 
85.  Training  courses  will  be  organized  following  an  annual  consultation  by  the  training 
specialist to determine the progressive needs of MFIs. The courses will include asset/liability 
management  and  risk  identification  and  mitigation;  product  development  and  pricing;  staff 
management,  performance  measurement,  and  provision  of  incentives;  loan  portfolio 
management; and governance and internal controls. Each course will last 6–12 days, have 15–
20 participants, and will cover 120 trainees. MFIs will meet the travel and per diem costs of the 
participants. The courses will be conducted by project staff or other experienced microfinance 
practitioners. Two workshops a year will be held for all MFI field staff and their managers and 
supervisors. While training will focus on MFIs progressing to licensing and regulation to take 
deposits, other MFIs will also be eligible to participate in domestic training programs. 
d.  Project Management

IV.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Objectives 
118.  The goal of the TA is to build strong, commercially viable MFIs capable of providing 
financial  services  to  MSEs  and  poor  households  while  developing  strong  regulatory  and 
supervisory  institutions  to  support  MFIs.  The  purpose  is  to  (i)  strengthen  the  supervisory 
capacity  of  NBT  to  oversee  MFIs,  and  (ii)  develop  the  capacity  of  MFIs  to  operate  as 
commercially viable financial institutions.  
B.  Scope 
119.  The TA will (i) formulate MFI financial models that feasibly fit microfinance needs and 
NGO capabilities; (ii) work closely with each MFI and candidate MFI in planning, evaluation of 
activities, development of new financial products, improvement of  governance and internal 
controls, and development of staff benefit packages linked to staff performance; (iii) work closely 
with the NBT MFI supervision section in refining off-site monitoring and appraisal of MFIs; 
(iv) work with NBT staff in developing efficient and effective procedures for on-site inspections; 
(v) explore possible linkages between commercial banks and MFIs in the joint development of 
products, placing of deposits, credit lines, and equity investment; (vi) prepare a baseline survey 
of MFI customers and a system for monitoring benefits received by households during the 
project; and (vii) obtain market information from households concerning demand for a range of 
financial services.

V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
124.  The adoption of a comprehensive financial systems development approach combined 
with intensive consultation with government agencies, NBT, NGOs and funding agencies is 
aimed at maximizing the benefits and impact and mitigating potentially significant risks.  
 
A.  Financial Analysis of Microfinance Institutions 
125.  Of current NGO microcredit programs, only a few can be expected to become licensed 
and  regulated  deposit-taking  MFIs  under  MSDP.  To  assess  the  potential  for  successful 
transformation, a detailed appraisal following the CGAP methodology for the appraisal of MFIs 
was conducted on ACTED and NABWT. These NGOs were selected as they indicated a strong 
interest in participating in the appraisal; both have recently divested nonfinancial operations to 
focus exclusively on microfinance, and are restructuring their management and operations to 
move to MFI licensing and regulation. NABWT is the largest domestic NGO by number of 
borrowers (5,906) and loan portfolio ($788,381). ACTED, while it has a smaller loan portfolio 
($120,633), is the third-largest NGO by number of clients (5,818). Detailed information on these 
NGOs’ operations is contained in Supplementary Appendix 1.  
 
126.  NABWT and ACTED have a strong financial base on which to transform themselves into 
licensed and regulated MFIs. 
 
B.  Benefits 
127.  The benefits derive from the individual policy and investment activities, and will include 
the following: 
 
(i)  Stable, Transparent Legal Foundation for Microfinance. An improved policy, 
legal,  and  regulatory  environment  will  create  the  conditions  to  formalize 
unlicensed, unregulated financial activity.  
 
(ii)  Increased  Financial  Diversity.  An  enabling  environment  and  substantial 
capacity building may result in the transformation of existing NGO microcredit 
programs into licensed and regulated MFIs, and the establishment of new MFIs.

27 
(iii)  Expansion of Financial Service Delivery. Through the licensing of at least two 
deposit-taking MFIs, the number of borrowers will increase from 15,000 to 38,000 
in five years, and the combined loan portfolios to $4 million.  
 
(iv)  Improved  Access  to  Capital  by  MSEs.  Formalized  microcredit  provided 
through viable MFIs will benefit thousands of MSEs that rely mainly on their own 
savings. With constant access to loans provided by commercially viable MFIs, 
MSEs can expand their businesses, benefiting owners and their families directly 
and the broader economy indirectly through increased economic activity.  
 
(v)  Safe Haven for Savings. MSEs, the poor, and rural dwellers will benefit directly 
from having facilities to safeguard savings. Monetary savings allow for income 
smoothing and accumulation of funds for investment. 
 
C.  Impact 
128.  The  development  of  a  strong  microfinance  sector  will  help  promote  economic 
development and reduce poverty. Tajikistan’s weak financial sector is not providing the impetus 
for broad-based development. MSDP attempts to address this situation by focusing on the 
development of microfinance services. 
 
1.  Economic Impact 
129.  MSDP will increase the number and diversity of financial institutions operating within the 
formal financial sector, which will not necessarily increase competition initially as MFIs and 
banks have different market segments and clientele. However, MFIs will require safe banking 
institutions for deposits, and MSDP will initiate the development of linkages for deposits and 
loans between MFIs and commercial banks. With increased institutional diversity and linkages 
with the commercial banking sector, an increased volume of deposits in the financial sector will 
help stimulate economic activity, increase domestic investment, deepen the financial sector, and 
contribute to economic growth. 
 
130.  The  indirect  economic  impact  will  derive  from  the  increased  economic  activity  and 
employment expected to be generated from the availability and access to more reliable and 
sustainable financial services from a varied range of financial institutions. However, finance 
alone will not necessarily generate these indirect economic impacts as other factors, including 
investment  laws  and  regulations,  business  capability,  etc.  will  affect  the  outcome  of 
entrepreneurial undertakings. 
 
2.  Impact on Poverty 
131.  NGOs  provide  limited  financial  services,  consisting  of  small  loans  and  compulsory 
savings, to their clients. They are generally from the poor and most vulnerable groups. Without 
the support of MSDP these programs will not be able to develop as sustainable and reliable 
financial institutions and, therefore, will be limited in their outreach. Further information on the 
impact  on  poverty  of  the  policy  loan  and  the  investment  loan  are  in  Appendix  10  and 
Supplementary Appendix 3, respectively. 
 
132.  The  establishment  of  an  enabling  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  environment  for 
microfinance  will  provide  a  more  conducive,  reliable,  and  transparent  framework  for 
microfinance.  The  environment  and  framework  will  broaden  the  young  and  undeveloped

28    
financial system to provide increased access to all segments of the population, contribute to 
equity, and reduce poverty. The framework will facilitate the establishment of new institutions 
and  further  the  development  of  existing  NGO  programs  into  more  sustainable  financial 
institutions.  Overall  access  by  the  poor  to  financial  services  should  increase  significantly. 
However, the extent of the increase in outreach will initially depend on funding available to 
expand activities. 
 
133.  The expansion of reliable and convenient access to financial services will also facilitate 
increased  enterprise  activities  as  more  people  can  take  advantage  of  existing  and  new 
opportunities. Many households save in nonfinancial forms, and these limit risk diversification 
and the contribution to resource allocation and economic growth. MSDP help mobilize financial 
savings, which will provide household security, allow self-financing of microenterprises, allow 
the poor to save for investment, and improve household financial management, smooth income 
flows and consumption patterns, and provide collateral for loans. 
 
134.  The transformation of at least two NGO microcredit programs into formally licensed and 
regulated financial institutions is expected to increase their outreach by about 100%. Based on 
the client profile, 75% of new clients are expected to be poor. The establishment of reliable and 
sustainable MFIs is aimed not only to enable poor clients to move out of poverty, but equally 
also to prevent those just above the poverty line from falling into deeper poverty.  
 
135.  Women account for most clients of NGO programs. Of the clients of four NGO agencies 
most  likely to  become  MFIs,  over  60%  (30–85%)  are  women.  While  some  MFIs  such  as 
NABWT focus on women, others such as AKF do not specifically target them. The overall 
impact of MSDP on women will depend on the NGOs included in the program and that become 
MFIs. These will ensure that women represent at least 50% of total clients. A gender analysis 
and plan is in Appendix 11. 
 
D.  Risk and Safeguards 
136.  Several risks are associated with MSDP. They are discussed below along with ways of 
mitigating them:  
 
(i)  Unstable  macroeconomic  environment  that  impacts  negatively  on  the 
subsectors where MSEs operate. The Government's continued commitment to 
reform  has  been  demonstrated  in  the  PRGF  signed  with  IMF.  Continued 
engagement with IMF and World Bank, and improving economic management 
are the key mitigating factors counterbalancing this risk. 
 
(ii)  Ineffective implementation of the draft microfinance law and regulations. 
Consulting  services  under  the  investment  loan  will  provide  expertise  and 
resources  to  NBT  to  implement  the  law  prudently,  and  create  an  effective 
regulatory and supervisory regime. USAID and IFC are also committed to seeing 
the law implemented.  
 
(iii)  Delays or difficulties in harmonizing related laws and the Tax Code as they 
relate to MFIs. Consulting resources of MSDP, and of USAID and IFC, which 
have signaled their commitment to harmonizing the draft law with existing laws 
and the Tax Code, will substantially mitigate this risk.

29 
(iv)  Delays or problems in transforming and/or establishing MFIs. The MPSC 
and TWG will continuously identify contentious issues and hold consultations on 
them, thereby mitigating this risk. Substantial ADB TA for MFI transformation, 
plus USAID and IFC support to transform individual NGO programs, will further 
reduce this risk.  
 
(v)  Operational and financial risks of PCBs. PCB operational and financial risk will 
be mitigated by strict criteria and performance monitoring developed under the 
project, supported by consulting services.  
 
(vi)  Operational and financial risks of MFIs. The attached TA will mitigate these 
through training and institutional capacity building. Operational risk can be further 
mitigated  by  MFI  borrowing  on  the  credit  line  to  finance  the  purchase  of 
appropriate information technology systems to improve accounting and financial 
reporting.

Tajikistan: Microfinance Systems Development Program 
 
The Republic of Tajikistan is continuing its transition process to a market-oriented economy. The 
macroeconomic situation has seen steady improvement, with GDP growing at an average annual 
rate of 7% since 1997. The growth, however, is not broad based and reflects favorable international 
market conditions for cotton and aluminum, which may prove temporary. Inflation has moderated 
since 1997 as well. Overall, we expect GDP to grow by 6% per year through 2005, with inflation 
being held to a maximum of 5% per year over the same period.   
 
Poverty reduction is a major objective of our development program. In June 2002 the Parliament 
approved a Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper, in which the Government estimates that 60% of the 
population live is living in poverty. Some poverty studies show a rate closer to 80%. In rural areas 
where more than 75% of the people live, there is a much greater degree of extreme poverty, 23% 
compared to 19% in urban areas. The Government of Tajikistan and the International Monetary 
Fund started implementation of the new three-year Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility Program 
(PRGF). The Program represents a great step forward for Tajikistan, and provides substantial 
resources with which to take on the task of poverty reduction.  
 
The principal objective of our Poverty Reduction Strategy is to achieve a fair distribution of the 
benefits of growth and ensure a rise in living standards of the poorest groups of the population. With 
this objective in mind, the Government aims to encourage the development of an effective financial 
sector capable of mobilizing savings and providing financial intermediation with particular attention to 
the needs of micro, small and medium-scale enterprises (SMEs), dekhkan farms and farmers, and 
people living in rural areas.   
 
There  has  been  achieved  significant  progress  with  support  of  IFOs  and  donors  in  expanding 
microcredit activities targeting MSEs and poorer rural households through programs organized and 
managed by non-governmental organizations in Tajikistan. Some of the best programs demonstrate 
measurable success, in terms of numbers of clients served, repayment rates (greater than 95%), 
and an ability to recover the cost of program administration through interest and fee charges. These 
successes  create  the  hope  that  by  applying  international  best  practices  in  microfinance,  well 
designed  programs  in  Tajikistan  can  grow  to  achieve  significant  outreach  and  financial  self-
sustainability.   
 
In order to meet the overall goals and specific objectives included in the National Poverty Reduction 
Strategy, and in consideration the positive developments within the small but growing microfinance

MSDP will help the Government to deepen the financial sector by increasing the outreach and

The Government, through the MF Policy, recognizes the leading role that domestic and international

urgent need for an enabling policy, legal and regulatory framework, to allow these organizations to 
expand their activities and transform themselves into safe and sound financial institutions. The MF

creation of the enabling environment. While process is important, the main emphasis of the MF

As part of the Government's program to promote microfinance, a Law on Microfinance Institutions is 
in its final stage of stakeholder review and consultation.  This law will create the proper legal

development  of  the  microfinance  sector.  The  Government  and  ADB  are  dedicated  to  further

GENDER ANALYSIS AND PLAN 
 
1.  Gender Status. Women in Tajikistan have suffered from the combined adverse impact 
of the country’s transition to a market economy and the 5–year civil conflict, which ensued 
immediately  after  independence.  Decreased  economic  activity,  death  of  men,  or  their  out 
migration  of  men  to  seek  jobs  outside  the  country  intensified  women’s  workload  and 
participation in the informal sector and low-paying formal labor market. Women’s limited access 
to productive and remunerative resources has constrained women’s economic opportunities and 
has confined rural women, especially, to coping strategies for survival. The collapse of social 
safety nets and social protection measures increased women’s household responsibilities and 
reduced their representation at the community and national levels. With the decrease in public 
social expenditures, gender disparities became more pronounced. Net enrolment ratio of girls to 
boys declined dramatically especially in the 7–18-year age bracket. Deteriorating health status 
among women and children worsened with the decline in health care services and reduction of 
municipal infrastructure, particularly potable drinking water.  
 
2.  The resumption of peace and the positive economic growth in recent years have yet to 
make a significant dent in material poverty and its multifaceted dimensions as well as on gender 
disparities. Disturbing trends that need to be addressed are the (i) sharp decline in labor force 
participation, especially among women; (ii) increasing out migration, particularly among young 
rural males, putting additional workload on women-headed households; and (iii) limited access 
to social services for women and children. Rural and poor women are the most disadvantaged 
as they must try to make both ends meet through intensive cultivation of small household plots 
while rearing their children and caring for the elderly.  
 
3.  Gender and Microfinance. The introduction of microfinance services by NGOs in major 
poverty-stricken and previously conflict-ridden regions during the second half of the 1990s was 
timely as it provided a lifeline support, especially to rural women. Access to microfinance 
services  gave  women  capital  and  became  for  most  the  foundation  to  build  sustainable 
livelihoods. By 2001 about 17 NGOs had provided microfinance to around 44,000 borrowers, 
about 60% of whom are women. Most women beneficiaries have accessed small-scale credit 
lines  to  engage  largely  in  trading  and  service-based  activities.  Some  recent  surveys  of 
international NGOs have shown that incomes derived from this informal source have improved 
beneficiaries’ revenue stream by 20–60%, and many female-headed and poor households have 
been able to solve their food insecurity. Women also benefited from the training as it honed their 
business  and  management  skills  and  improved  their  awareness  of  their  human  rights.  As 
immediate income needs are met, women beneficiaries engage in community development 
activities, participate in local governance, and policy dialogues, and network with other women 
groups.  
 
4.  Gender Issues. Partnerships and networking between NGOs and Government have 
likewise improved the environment for women’s economic empowerment. The basic framework 
for mainstreaming the gender agenda into the national political arena is laid out in the National 
Plan of Action for Women’s Advancement and the National Program for Equal Opportunities 
between Women and Men. However, more policy, regulatory, and supervisory reforms are 
required to expand the outreach of microfinance services. To date, only about 8% of the total 
population has access to microfinance services. While women clients outnumber men, demand 
for microfinance services remains large and unmet. For instance, microfinance institution (MFI) 
deposit schemes are prohibited legally, not only inhibiting MFIs’ capacity to mobilize domestic 
resources but also harming women in general as they save more than men. Women also 
participate mainly in group lending schemes rather than higher-end capital activities, partly

2.  Profitability/Self-Sustainability 
 
9.  In the case of commercial banks, profitability is measured generally in terms of return on 
equity and return on assets, and these measures are relevant for MFIs as well. MFIs, which are 
often recipients of noncommercial support and/or funding, also need to consider operational 
self-sufficiency and financial self-sufficiency indicators that show the capacity of an MFIs to 
continue functioning once support comes to an end. The following indicators will be applied to 
participating MFIs to measure profitability and self-sustainability: 
 
(i)  Adjusted return on equity. Net operating income less taxes/adjusted average 
equity. Measures the MFI's ability to generate profits that provide a reasonable 
return to investors. 
(ii)  Adjusted return on assets. Net operating income less taxes/adjusted average 
total assets. Measures the MFI's ability to generate revenue from investments, 
and convert revenue into profit.  
(iii)  OSS  ratio.  Operating  revenue/(operating  expense  +  unadjusted  financing 
expense + loan loss provision expense). Measures the MFI's ability to cover all of 
its actual expenses from its revenue stream. 
(iv)  Adjusted financial self-sufficiency ratio. Adjusted operating revenue/adjusted 
(operating expense + financial expense + loan loss provision expense - net 
extraordinary  income).  Measures  the  MFI's  ability  to  cover  its  total  costs, 
including actual costs and imputed costs, of which imputed costs are added to 
simulate full commercial operating conditions. 
 
10.  Adjustments essentially represent imputed costs that MFIs often do not incur directly due 
to financial support from funding agencies or other agencies. Inflation must also be considered. 
The value, in real terms, of an MFI's capital must also be maintained. Only after imputing costs 
related to inflation and neutralizing the benefits of operational or financial subsidies is it possible 
to determine whether an MFI is commercially viable or approaching commercial viability. After 
adding imputed costs (or subtracting imputed benefits), adjustments to income statement and 
balance  sheet  figures  must  be  made.  The  PMU  will  be  responsible  for  monitoring  MFI 
performance against these profitability and self-sustainability indicators, and will calculate and 
adjust the income statement and balance sheet data according to criteria provided to the PMU 
by the project.

11.  The MFI's performance at loan collection must be monitored. Loan classification and 
loan loss provisioning are as important to an MFI as to a commercial bank. NBT regulations 
developed for MFIs are assumed to incorporate similar loan classification and provisioning 
requirements  as  those  applied  to  commercial  banks.  New  MFIs  should  be  provided  with 
additional indicators of portfolio quality to help develop a strong credit culture. The following 
indicators will be applied by the PCBs and PMU to monitor MFI portfolio quality:  
 
(i)  Portfolio at risk (PAR) ratio. PAR (over 30 days)/gross loan portfolio.This is a 
very conservative indicator of portfolio quality, and measures the financial impact

  4.  Efficiency 
 
12.  MFIs must  achieve sizeable outreach, which is in many ways a proxy  measure of 
poverty impact. MFIs must also be profitable to attract more investors and capital. Managing 
credit  risk  properly  is  also  important,  because  loan  losses  can  quickly  erode  capital  and 
undermine financial strength. From the point of view of the customer, the MFI must operate 
efficiently, that is, manage its cost structure to provide services as cost-effectively as possible. 
Cost-effectiveness means that the MFI can offer credit products at a lower interest rate, or pay a 
higher rate of interest on deposits. MSDP will monitor the efficiency of participating MFIs by 
subjecting MFIs to the following efficiency indicators:  
 
(i)  Efficiency  ratio. Adjusted operating expense/adjusted (net interest margin – 
provisions for loan losses + other recurring income). Adjusted operating expense 
is the numerator. This indicator is a standard banking indicator of efficiency as it 
shows how many units of net revenue are generated for each unit of expenditure; 
it is, in effect, an input-output ratio.  
 
(ii)  Cost  per  borrower.  Adjusted  operating  expense/average  number  of  active 
borrowers. This is an appropriate indicator for MFIs reaching low-end clients 
because it neutralizes the effect of loan sizes. 
 
(iii)  Assets per employee. Operating expense/number of employees. Measures the 
productivity of the MFI's employees.  
 
(iv)  Loans per credit officer. Total active loans/number of credit officers. Measures 
the productivity of the credit department's operations, key to an MFI's profitability.
